description: From homoe- (from Ancient Greek ὅμοιος (hómoios, “of like kind”, “similar”)) + -o- + -merous (from Ancient Greek μέρος (méros, “portion”)).

adjectives.description: homoeomerous (comparative more homoeomerous, superlative most homoeomerous)

entries.meaning: (biology) Having similar quantities or variations pertaining to parts of structure.
Being the same whether whole or divided into parts.
examples: A lump of bronze differs from a statue in being homoeomerous; it is divisible into lumps of bronze, whereas the statue is not divisible into statues.
